thread.title: Time for Game 5 as Mets shut down by Clayton Kershaw in 3-1 loss to Los Angeles Dodgers | Rapid reaction
thread.title_full: Time for Game 5 as Mets shut down by Clayton Kershaw in 3-1 loss to Los Angeles Dodgers | Rapid reaction | NJ.com

author: Mike Vorkunov | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Time for Game 5 as Mets shut down by Clayton Kershaw in 3-1 loss to Los Angeles Dodgers | Rapid reaction
text:
NEW YORK ‚Äî There was no getting to Clayton Kershaw this time. The Dodgers' ace discarded his demons of playoff starts past and easily mowed the Mets in Los Angeles' 3-1 Game 4 win at Citi Field.
Kershaw was barely hittable. The Mets managed just three all night. Daniel Murphy smacked a solo home run in the fourth but there was little else.
And Murphy's home run could not bring the Mets out of their hole. They fell behind 3-0 in the third when the Dodgers rallied against starter Steven Matz. With three singles and a two-run double by former Met Justin Turner they took an advantage they never lost.
It sends the Mets and Dodgers back to Los Angeles for one winner-take-all Game 5 at Dodger Stadium. The Mets will have Jacob deGrom on the mound and the Dodgers will start Zack Greinke.
"You're going up and Kershaw and Greinke again, you want to try to win this as quickly as possible," David Wright said Monday night. "You definitely don't want to go back to L.A. and have Greinke there."
Now they will. Still, the Mets always knew it would go like this. In a meeting before this NLDS began, Terry Collins told his team that they'd have to navigate the two Cy Young candidates twice each.
"What's it like?" Collins said. "Not a lot of fun knowing you gotta face those two guys. But we knew going into this."
STARTING PITCHER
Steven Matz was rusty in his first start in 18 days. He allowed three runs over five innings, giving up six hits and walking two. He was bitten by a three-run third inning for the Dodgers when they notched four hits, including a two-run double by Justin Turner. Matz hadn't started for the Mets since Sept. 24 because of a back injury.
IN CASE YOU MISSED IT
#5üí™üèøüí™üèø pic.twitter.com/eTtjjJ0S3E
‚Äî Jose Reyes (@lamelaza_7) October 14, 2015
STORYLINES TO FOLLOW
‚Ä¢ Despite Clayton Kershaw's struggles against left-handed hitters in Game 1, manager Terry Collins never considered starting Michael Conforto. Instead he stuck with Juan Lagares in center field and Yoenis Cespedes in left again, using the same lineup as Monday night. Conforto came in to pinch-hit in the eighth for Lagares and flied out to right.
"We had a big night," Collins said. "I said, you know what, I'm not going to mess with it."
‚Ä¢ While Collins has grown increasingly reliant on Bartolo Colon this series, he's not ready to make his bridge to Jeurys Familia.
‚Ä¢ Noah Syndergaard wasn't available in Game 4. Collins said he was still sore from his Game 2 start.
BEHIND THE SCENES
. @Mets owner Fred Wilpon with a nifty, behind-the-back throw during #Mets batting practice. #MLBPlayoffs pic.twitter.com/0h1E6vh8ZR
‚Äî Andrew Mills (@AndyMills_NJ) October 13, 2015
WHAT'S NEXT Game 5. Dodger Stadium. Win or go home.
